data.text:
@AvivShachak @haneenshib Thank you! 
I would be more than happy to send you a copy
@yavetz1 @haneenshib I look forward to reading it. Nice to see this work coming from my alma mater.
I was really happy to finally refer to the work of some of my favorite digital health and crisis scholars, like @was3210 @alelovari , @UFScholar and many others.

The results are now published online in our new paper: 
https://t.co/FYDcIwvfc0

Also, the majority of participants described feeling a lack of clear government information due to the multiplicity of government voices and poor access to accurate health and official information via government websites and portals.

We found out that most participants indicated feelings of media fatigue due to increased exposure to news media and social media, to the point of experiencing information overload. This led to a tendency to adhere to information mediators like friends, family, and opinion leaders https://t.co/VGmVR6ErgM

Starting with the qualitative phase, we sat down (virtually, of course) with 25 Israeli citizens and asked them about their information needs about covid, their fears, dilemmas, and their information-seeking behavior and sources.
